etymology.description: 什(什) (shén, "what") and 麼(麼) (me, marker for questions or emphasis)
etymology.interpretation: 什麼(什麼) (shénme, "what") combines 什(什) (shén, "what") with 麼(麼) (me, a particle often used to form questions or provide emphasis), creating a term used to ask questions or refer to things in an indefinite manner. This pairing is a common way to formulate questions in Chinese.
etymology.simplification: Simplified form 什麼 is 什么.

examples.chinese: 你今天穿什么(你今天穿什麼)？
妈妈问孩子(媽媽問孩子)，想要什么(想要什麼)？
examples.pinyin: Māmā wèn háizi, xiǎng yào shénme?
examples.english: Mother asked the child, 'What do you want?'

examples.chinese: 请问这是什么(請問這是什麼)？
